author: 2fingers
body:
That's a pretty insane return for the trading plan that you're describing. I have no idea how you could have gotten that large of a return doing such high probability credit spreads. Credit spreads are a lot more common than you think though, check out Tasty Trade. 

I'm skeptical you'd get filled anywhere close to $1.25 for that AVGO trade, there's not enough liquidity

author: LWinthorpe3
body:
How is selling spreads "rarely used"?

Why not just link to any number of professionally written articles about spreads?

Is this a shill for AVGO?

author: my_other_account_471
body:
I started investing about 1.5 month back, and my first $1K (I have invested $5K now) went to Ford (It was during Biden's visit to Ford plant), Nvidia (since I think that it is a better choice to crypto, and if cryptos go up, so does Nvidia). Gradually I invested and additional $4K to companies like Microsoft, Google, Nike, Adobe, Boeing, Airbus, Broadcom, T-Mobile, Fedex etc. and a couple of ETFs (SPYD and SPYG). 

This is not an investment advice. This just what I did with my first $5K but that was 1.5 month ago.

author: WoodpeckerAlarmed239
body:
All I have is a Roth IRA and can only put in $6,000 a year. I've been at it for 6 years now and it's doing pretty well. I don't make a whole lot of money so it's a perfect set up for me. I max it out, buy some solid names at good prices and try to hold them.

The plan is obviously retirement. But if anything comes up before then, I can take out money with no penalties and do what I need to do, maybe a down payment on a house one day.

If there's one thing I wish I did more, was take some risks for high returns. But I don't think now is the time for that. I hate holding a stock with no dividend and just watching it bounce around so I go with dividend payers. 

My positions are: SWKS, LMT, AAPL, CSCO, QCOM, KLIC, INTC, KMI. A bit tech heavy but I know they will be relevant for years to come.

I also have a problem buying a stock "early" and selling it before it really takes off. Broadcom and Align technologies are the two that come to mind.

author: 2fingers
body: Honestly it seems like you are lying about this. You didn't mention IVR or any of the greeks and the only specific trade you mentioned (AVGO) obviously wouldn't get filled, except on a paper account or in backtesting. You're very defensive for someone who makes such a large return

author: LeocantoKosta_
body: NVDA is great, seems a little expensive though. Long term probably doesn't matter. I would avoid Intel. I like the trio of semi equipment companies - ASML, LRCX, AMAT. I also like some of the fabless chipmakers like AVGO, TXN, and NXP. TSMC might be good as well. Ultimately, you could spread out across some names, or maybe a semiconductor ETF like SOXX or PSI.

author: ITM_ENRON_CALLS
body: BRK.B, AAPL, AVGO

author: Lucetar
body:
Thoughts on FSELX? Fidelity Select Semiconductor Portfolio.

I see semiconductors being used for more and more products in the future and the demand never really going down. 

Holdings include: Nvidia, Intel, Qualcomm, Broadcom, and Micron. 

Expense Ratio .7% Seems a little high to me but not horrible. 

I already have a 457b in a target date fund from work I am putting into and a Roth IRA in VOO. This would be a small part of my Roth IRA and intend to hold for the next 20-30 years or so.

author: Chance_Island2704
body:
DOCU is a solid company. If I wasn't already overloaded on tech, it'd be near the top of my list.

EDIT: AVGO is also strong. All they do is print money.

author: apooroldinvestor
body: Cool! I just added 3.117 shares of AVGO today.

author: Ok_Ganache_789
body: I use a dividend strategy as a way to provide supplemental income. Currently my dividends and interest on high yield bonds generates around 10k/yr. I look for stocks with low betas and companies whose products are fairly inelastic. I track these in a seperate etrade account where I’m leas concerned with capital appreciation. Some high div stocks to consider are $MO, $AB, $STWD, $VZ, $MMM, $AVGO to cite a few.

author: exaltedgod
body:
> Cause their phones failed, they’ve moved onto cyber security and their stock hasn’t adjusted to that change yet.

Gonna get downvoted for this because I am going against the hive.... As someone in the cybersecurity field and tracks that space, there is nothing to reflect. BB bought up a mediocre antivirus tool (Cylance) busted their butts to get it on the same playing field as other EDR products (endpoint detection and response, think AV software amped up and without all the false positives) but they are still bottom of the pack (review the Gartner quadrant [here](https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2021/05/11/gartner-names-microsoft-a-leader-in-the-2021-endpoint-protection-platforms-magic-quadrant/)).

> Similar companies in the industry are priced around $40-60 mark but I think they have a lot more potential imo. 

EDR vendors that be competitors to Black Berry are as follows:  

* CrowdStrike - $216
* SentinelOne - Private Company
* Microsoft Defender - $245
* VMware Carbon Black - $159
* Broadcom Symantec ATP - $23
* Malwarebytes - Private Company
* Cisco AMP - $54

Whoever you are listening too on BlackBerry and "cybersecurity" needs to do some basic research. The Cylance product (and the functions it brings) they bought is basically dead and has zero room for growth. That is 1/3 of their entire offering. Other services and capabilities by BlackBerry aren't used by large firms any more. Companies like FireEye, Mandiant, CrowdStrike, etc have better IR and forensic services.

author: zenwarrior01
body: Utter nonsense.  If stocks and TA worked so perfectly like that then you may as well buy options straight up and make much more than that, but as everyone with any experience whatsoever knows, they do not work like that.  Up one day, down the next, especially in recent months.  Then to suggest that AVGO is such a candidate defies basic TA.  Serious resistance at 485-490, and every time it hit that it fell hard.  If the general market is weaker, it's likely to get hit sooner.  You can sense the hesitancy in the stock movement the past week.  The trade will still likely succeed, as is the case with any OTM Credit Put Spreads, but the much larger downside isn't worth the limited gain IMO... or at least it's not the easy money you think it is.

author: 10xwannabe
body:
Okay guess you are not invested then?  :)  

Not to start a debate, but I would be careful sitting on your high horse looking down on all of us before you look at yourself.  If you do any broad based index fund investing then you are undoubtedly invested in tobacco and alcohol companies.  Tobacco is linked to the 5 leading causes of death in America (likely same in Canada).  Alcohol is related to 50% of all fatal car accidents in America (likely same in Canada).  If you wear sneakers or any type of clothing you would be surprised what type of at best adult and at worst child sweat shops they are made from in third-third world companies. If you like green energy you would be surprised at how much oil is needed to make green energy products.

Trust me NO ONE really can stand on a pedestal in this day in age.  Just matters what you accept and what you choose to not be cognizant of in your daily life.  Running a google search itself consumes energy (carbon footprint).  I doubt you are outside planting trees to make up for it.    

BTW, sticking to this discussion.  How many water wells has Disney (part owner) and Nat Geo dug or paid for in Namibia vs. RECAF?  RECAF cares about making money, but as far as I know they have done more for the Namibian people then Nat Geo does/has despite the latter making millions of their story to sell articles. 

The problem with the green folks is they are ALWAYS hypocritical.  How did those journalist get to Namibia to do the article?  They flew.  Did they plant trees or pay for conversion of methane gases in landfills to make their flights carbon neutral?  Nope.  

Just keep in mind the old adage if you point one finger at someone there are 3 pointing right back at you.

author: LaOnionLaUnion
body: I think it’s going to be a major player in ML/AI coupled with its products. As a developer, their play with arm chips seems huge. Having a development machine that runs arm natively and which is already popular with developers is probably a bigger step than most people are cognizant of. It’s hardly a home run at this point but it reminds me that they are still making big Silicon Valley style plays and thinking big picture.

author: ElCalvo069
body:
You have 7 months to go so that's 2 earnings reports and potentially some holiday sales info. If your analysis leads you to believe that you'll be ITM then wait it out. 

Just be cognizant of time decay (theta) which accelerates the closer you get to expiry and eats into the value of the option.

And like others mentioned - have an exit plan before executing the trade.

author: juan62389
body:
CORNING, N.Y., June 03, 2021 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Corning Incorporated (NYSE:GLW) today introduced its latest innovation, Corning SMF-28® Contour optical fiber, to help telecommunications operators address the ever-expanding number of connected devices, build-out of 5G networks, and advances in cloud computing.​
Networks perform at their best when errors are minimized during fiber installation and when existing infrastructure is used efficiently during upgrades. Corning engineered SMF-28 Contour fiber to meet those needs. This groundbreaking product will allow customers to seamlessly upgrade their optical infrastructures, enabling the cost-effective deployment of future-ready networks. The fiber offers:
